dt: {bc}a comprehensive and fundamental law, doctrine, or assumption
{bc}the laws or facts of nature underlying the working of an artificial device

dt.t: such {wi}principles{/wi} of human nature as greed and curiosity

dt: {bc}an ingredient (such as a chemical) that exhibits or imparts a characteristic quality

dt.t: prepared to accept the proposition {it}in principle{/it}

pt: Evidence of confusion between {it}principle{/it} and {it}principal{/it} can be found even in publications overseen by professional editors. To keep these words straight, remember that {it}principle{/it} functions only as a noun, and in its most common uses refers to a basic rule or law, as in
If you are looking for an adjective form of this word, you must use {it}principled{/it}, as in
{it}Principal{/it} functions as both a noun and an adjective. The noun has various meanings referring to someone with controlling authority
, but also has meanings relating to finance, law, and architecture. As an adjective, {it}principal{/it} typically means {ldquo}most important,{rdquo} as in

quotes.t: Better, of course, to take a higher road, operate on the {qword}principle{/qword} of service and see if things don't turn out better …
Urban guerrilla warfare was futile against a thermonuclear superstate that would stop at nothing to defend the profit {qword}principle{/qword}.
Pointlessness was life's {qword}principle{/qword}, and it spread its sadness.

et: Middle English, from Middle French {it}principe, principle{/it}, from Old French, from Latin {it}principium{/it} beginning, from {it}princip-, princeps{/it} initiator {ma}{mat|prince|}{/ma}
shortdef: a comprehensive and fundamental law, doctrine, or assumption
a rule or code of conduct
in opposition to what someone believes

dt: {bc}a theory in economics: an increase or decrease in income induces a corresponding but magnified change in investment

shortdef: a theory in economics: an increase or decrease in income induces a corresponding but magnified change in investment

dt: {bc}conditions that are observed in the universe must allow the observer to exist
{bc}the universe must have properties that make inevitable the existence of intelligent life

shortdef: either of two principles in cosmology:
conditions that are observed in the universe must allow the observer to exist —called also weak anthropic principle
the universe must have properties that make inevitable the existence of intelligent life —called also strong anthropic principle

dt: {bc}a principle in hydrodynamics: the pressure in a stream of fluid is reduced as the speed of the flow is increased

shortdef: a principle in hydrodynamics: the pressure in a stream of fluid is reduced as the speed of the flow is increased

dt: {bc}a principle in physics: no two particles (such as electrons) in an atom or molecule can have the same set of quantum numbers

shortdef: a principle in physics: no two particles (such as electrons) in an atom or molecule can have the same set of quantum numbers —called also Pauli exclusion principle

dt: {bc}an observation: in a hierarchy employees tend to rise to the level of their incompetence

shortdef: an observation: in a hierarchy employees tend to rise to the level of their incompetence

dt: {bc}a tendency for individual behavior to be directed toward immediate satisfaction of instinctual drives and immediate relief from pain or discomfort

shortdef: a tendency for individual behavior to be directed toward immediate satisfaction of instinctual drives and immediate relief from pain or discomfort
